title: Manure and nutrient production bedding design tips for beef barns

tasks.task: Discussing the transition from open feedlots to bedded barns and considerations for manure management.
subtasks: Scrapping and cleaning barns weekly instead of bi-annually.
Designing barns to minimize cattle injury while cleaning.
Capturing nutrients from urine and organic matter.
Understanding ammonia volatilization and its relation to manure smells.
Calculating stocking density for cattle in confined spaces.
Managing urine depth and manure accumulation based on stocking density.
Considering the cost and application rate of bedding materials.
Evaluating manure storage options for ease of handling and minimal spoilage.
Adjusting bedding needs based on season and cattle size.
Understanding the increased bedding requirements in summer versus winter.
Designing push walls and curves in barns for equipment safety and efficiency.
Planning for deep pit manure storage and bi-annual pumping.
Managing manure spreaders and tractor equipment.
Adapting to community standards for manure storage and odor control.
Applying captured nutrients to fields with high P and K requirements.
